title: Isaiah Chapter 38 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 38 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 38 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 38.

questions.question: Who came to Hezekiah when he was sick unto death?
options: Isaiah the prophet
Elijah the prophet
Jeremiah the prophet
Ezekiel the prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah the prophet
questions.explanation: Isaiah the prophet the son of Amoz came unto Hezekiah when he was sick, as stated in Isaiah 38:1.

questions.question: What did Isaiah say the LORD told Hezekiah to do because he would die?
options: Set thine house in order
Build an altar
Prepare for battle
Give charity to the poor
questions.correctAnswer: Set thine house in order
questions.explanation: Isaiah told Hezekiah that the LORD said, 'Set thine house in order: for thou shalt die, and not live,' as found in Isaiah 38:1.

questions.question: How did Hezekiah respond when told he would die?
options: He turned his face toward the wall and prayed
He became angry and rebellious
He fell asleep
He sent a message to the king of Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: He turned his face toward the wall and prayed
questions.explanation: Hezekiah turned his face toward the wall and prayed unto the LORD, according to Isaiah 38:2.

questions.question: What did Hezekiah ask the LORD to remember in his prayer?
options: How he walked before God in truth and a perfect heart
His many sacrifices
His wealth and kingdom
His loyalty to the king of Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: How he walked before God in truth and a perfect heart
questions.explanation: Hezekiah prayed asking the LORD to remember how he walked before Him in truth and with a perfect heart, as described in Isaiah 38:3.

questions.question: How many years did the LORD add to Hezekiah's life?
options: Fifteen years
Ten years
Twenty years
Five years
questions.correctAnswer: Fifteen years
questions.explanation: God said He would add fifteen years to Hezekiah's life, as stated in Isaiah 38:5.

questions.question: What city did God promise to deliver and defend?
options: Jerusalem
Babylon
Nineveh
Samaria
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem
questions.explanation: God promised to deliver and defend the city from the king of Assyria, which was Jerusalem, as in Isaiah 38:6.

questions.question: What sign did God give to Hezekiah to prove He would fulfill His promise?
options: The shadow on the sundial of Ahaz going backward ten degrees
A rainbow in the sky
A dove descending
A burning bush
questions.correctAnswer: The shadow on the sundial of Ahaz going backward ten degrees
questions.explanation: God said the shadow on the sundial of Ahaz would go backward ten degrees as a sign, according to Isaiah 38:8.

questions.question: What did Hezekiah say he thought would happen to him in his sickness?
options: He would go to the gates of the grave
He would be healed immediately
He would conquer his enemies
He would become king
questions.correctAnswer: He would go to the gates of the grave
questions.explanation: Hezekiah said, 'I shall go to the gates of the grave,' expressing his belief he would die, in Isaiah 38:10.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'For the grave cannot praise thee, death cannot celebrate thee: they that go down into the pit cannot hope for thy ______.'
options: truth
mercy
power
salvation
questions.correctAnswer: truth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:18 states that those who go down into the pit cannot hope for God's truth.

questions.question: Who is described as praising God in Isaiah 38:19?
options: The living
The dead
The angels
The prophets
questions.correctAnswer: The living
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:19 states that the living shall praise God.

questions.question: What did Hezekiah say about his eyes in his lament?
options: Mine eyes fail with looking upward
Mine eyes are filled with joy
Mine eyes see the angels
Mine eyes are closed in peace
questions.correctAnswer: Mine eyes fail with looking upward
questions.explanation: Hezekiah says in Isaiah 38:14 that his eyes fail with looking upward as part of his mourning.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah instructed that a lump of figs be used as a plaster on Hezekiah's boil.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:21 says to take a lump of figs and lay it as a plaster on the boil for healing.

questions.question: True or False: Hezekiah asked what sign he would receive before going to the house of the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:22 records Hezekiah asking what sign he would receive before going to the house of the LORD.

questions.question: What did Hezekiah say about his soul's condition before God delivered him?
options: He had great bitterness for peace
He was joyful and content
He was indifferent
He was angry with God
questions.correctAnswer: He had great bitterness for peace
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:17 says Hezekiah had great bitterness for peace before God delivered his soul.

questions.question: True or False: Hezekiah believed he would see the LORD in the land of the living before his illness.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:11 says Hezekiah believed he would not see the LORD in the land of the living.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 38 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 38 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Isaiah 38, what biblical truth would you share about prayer and God's response?
options: God hears our prayers and sees our tears, offering mercy and healing.
God ignores our prayers when we are in distress.
Prayer has no effect on our circumstances.
We must earn God's favor through works before He answers.
questions.correctAnswer: God hears our prayers and sees our tears, offering mercy and healing.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:5 shows that God heard Hezekiah's prayer and saw his tears, then extended his life by fifteen years. This teaches us that God is attentive and compassionate toward sincere prayer (Isaiah 38:2-5).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 38 teach about faith and trust in God during serious illness or hardship?
options: Trusting God involves honest prayer and hope for His deliverance.
Faith means ignoring illness and refusing help.
God always heals immediately without delay.
We should be fearful and hopeless when sick.
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God involves honest prayer and hope for His deliverance.
questions.explanation: Hezekiah honestly prayed to God in his distress (Isaiah 38:2-3) and expressed trust that God would recover him (Isaiah 38:16). This model shows faith includes turning to God with sincerity and hope.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and repentance can we draw from Hezekiah's prayer in Isaiah 38?
options: Hezekiah acknowledged his dependence on God and sought His mercy.
Hezekiah boasted about his righteousness and demanded healing.
Hezekiah blamed others for his sickness.
Hezekiah refused to pray or seek forgiveness.
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah acknowledged his dependence on God and sought His mercy.
questions.explanation: Hezekiah prayed with a perfect heart before God and wept, showing humility and dependence (Isaiah 38:3). He confessed and sought God's mercy rather than self-reliance (Isaiah 38:17).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 38 encourage believers to live with contentment and gratitude, even after trials?
options: By praising God and singing songs in His house all their days.
By complaining about their suffering and loss.
By isolating themselves from fellowship.
By focusing only on the length of life, not its quality.
questions.correctAnswer: By praising God and singing songs in His house all their days.
questions.explanation: Hezekiah resolved to sing songs to the Lord in the house of the Lord all his life because the Lord was ready to save him (Isaiah 38:20). This teaches gratitude and worship after deliverance.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with despair, feeling like life is ending. Based on Isaiah 38, what biblical truth would you share about God's sovereignty over life and death?
options: God controls life and death and can extend days beyond what seems certain.
Death is final and there is no hope beyond the grave.
Humans have complete control over their lifespan.
God is indifferent to human suffering.
questions.correctAnswer: God controls life and death and can extend days beyond what seems certain.
questions.explanation: God promised Hezekiah an additional fifteen years (Isaiah 38:5), demonstrating His control over life and death. The grave cannot praise God, but the living can (Isaiah 38:18-19).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 38 teach about the importance of honesty before God in prayer?
options: Hezekiah openly expressed his fear and sorrow to God.
Hezekiah pretended to be strong and unafraid.
Hezekiah refused to speak about his feelings.
Hezekiah blamed God for his sickness.
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah openly expressed his fear and sorrow to God.
questions.explanation: Hezekiah turned to the wall and prayed honestly, weeping sore and expressing his anguish (Isaiah 38:2-3, 14). This shows the value of transparency in prayer.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 38 suggest about God's willingness to forgive and forget sins?
options: God cast all Hezekiah's sins behind His back in love.
God held Hezekiah's sins against him forever.
God required Hezekiah to perform sacrifices first.
God ignored Hezekiah's repentance.
questions.correctAnswer: God cast all Hezekiah's sins behind His back in love.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:17 says God delivered Hezekiah in love and cast all his sins behind His back, illustrating God's forgiving nature.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 38, a sign was given to Hezekiah to confirm God's promise to extend his life.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:7-8 describes the sign where the shadow on the sundial moved backward ten degrees, confirming God's promise.

questions.question: True or False: Hezekiah doubted God's ability to save him and refused to pray.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hezekiah prayed sincerely and trusted God for recovery, as shown in Isaiah 38:2-3 and 16.

questions.question: A believer wants to understand how to respond to God's discipline and trials. What does Isaiah 38 teach about this?
options: Respond with humility, repentance, and trust in God's love.
Respond with anger and rebellion.
Ignore God and focus on self.
Deny the trial and pretend all is well.
questions.correctAnswer: Respond with humility, repentance, and trust in God's love.
questions.explanation: Hezekiah humbled himself before God, prayed with a perfect heart, and acknowledged God's loving deliverance (Isaiah 38:3,17).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 38 demonstrate the role of a prophet in spiritual encouragement and healing?
options: Isaiah delivered God's message and prescribed a remedy to Hezekiah.
Isaiah ignored Hezekiah's condition.
Isaiah told Hezekiah to rely on his own strength.
Isaiah refused to visit Hezekiah.
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah delivered God's message and prescribed a remedy to Hezekiah.
questions.explanation: Isaiah spoke God's word to Hezekiah (Isaiah 38:1,4-5) and instructed a fig plaster for healing (Isaiah 38:21), showing prophetic care.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 38 teach about praising God in community and family life?
options: The living praise God and the father teaches children His truth.
Praise is only private and not shared.
Children should not learn about God's truth.
Praising God is optional and unnecessary.
questions.correctAnswer: The living praise God and the father teaches children His truth.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:19 emphasizes that the living praise the Lord and fathers make His truth known to their children, highlighting family worship.

questions.question: A believer wonders how to maintain integrity and honesty in their spiritual life. What lesson does Isaiah 38 provide?
options: Be honest with God about fears and sins, trusting His mercy.
Hide your struggles to appear righteous.
Blame others for your failures.
Avoid prayer when troubled.
questions.correctAnswer: Be honest with God about fears and sins, trusting His mercy.
questions.explanation: Hezekiah openly confessed his fears and sought God's mercy (Isaiah 38:3,14,17), modeling integrity before God.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Isaiah 38:16, 'O Lord, by these things men live, and in all these things is the life of my ______.'
options: spirit
body
heart
mind
questions.correctAnswer: spirit
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:16 states that by these things men live and in all these things is the life of the spirit, showing reliance on God for spiritual life.

questions.question: What practical guidance about healing does Isaiah 38 provide through the prophet Isaiah's instructions?
options: Use natural remedies as God directs alongside faith in Him.
Avoid any medicine and trust only prayer.
Rely solely on doctors without prayer.
Reject all forms of healing.
questions.correctAnswer: Use natural remedies as God directs alongside faith in Him.
questions.explanation: Isaiah instructed placing a lump of figs on Hezekiah's boil (Isaiah 38:21), showing that God can work through practical means.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 38 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 38.

questions.question: What sign did the LORD give Hezekiah to confirm the promise of added years to his life?
options: The shadow on the sundial moving backward ten degrees
A burning bush that was not consumed
A rainbow in the sky
A pillar of fire by night
questions.correctAnswer: The shadow on the sundial moving backward ten degrees
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:7-8 describe the sign God gave Hezekiah: the shadow on the sundial of Ahaz moved backward ten degrees to confirm the promise of extended life.

questions.question: How does Hezekiah describe his condition before his recovery in his writing?
options: He felt as if his age was departing and he was cut off like a weaver
He felt like a mighty lion roaring in strength
He compared himself to a flourishing tree by the riverside
He described himself as victorious and unshaken
questions.correctAnswer: He felt as if his age was departing and he was cut off like a weaver
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:11-12 uses the imagery of a shepherd's tent being removed and life being cut off like a weaver, showing Hezekiah's sense of impending death.

questions.question: What was Hezekiah's response when Isaiah told him to set his house in order because he would die?
options: He turned toward the wall and prayed to the LORD
He immediately accepted his fate without protest
He sought help from the king of Assyria
He sent messengers to other prophets for advice
questions.correctAnswer: He turned toward the wall and prayed to the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:2 recounts that Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to God after hearing the prophecy of his impending death.

questions.question: Which phrase in Hezekiah's prayer reflects his appeal to his own righteous conduct before God?
options: "I have walked before thee in truth and with a perfect heart"
"I have built an altar to the LORD in my city"
"I have conquered my enemies with your help"
"I have kept the law of Moses faithfully"
questions.correctAnswer: "I have walked before thee in truth and with a perfect heart"
questions.explanation: In Isaiah 38:3, Hezekiah appeals to God by recalling his faithful and upright walk before Him.

questions.question: How many years did God add to Hezekiah's life as a result of his prayer?
options: Fifteen years
Ten years
Twenty years
Five years
questions.correctAnswer: Fifteen years
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:5 clearly states that God promised to add fifteen years to Hezekiah's life.

questions.question: According to the text, what was the fate of the city during Hezekiah's extended life?
options: It would be delivered from the king of Assyria
It would be destroyed by invaders
It would be abandoned
It would be conquered by Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: It would be delivered from the king of Assyria
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:6 promises that God would deliver the city from the hand of the king of Assyria and defend it.

questions.question: Which metaphor does Hezekiah use to describe his suffering and the approach of death?
options: Like a lion breaking his bones
Like a tree shedding its leaves
Like a raging storm at sea
Like a warrior in battle
questions.correctAnswer: Like a lion breaking his bones
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:13 uses the simile of a lion breaking bones to express the severity of Hezekiah's suffering and his sense of impending death.

questions.question: What does Hezekiah say about the grave and death in relation to praising God?
options: The grave and death cannot praise or celebrate God
The grave rejoices in God's truth
Death is a place of eternal worship
The pit celebrates God’s truth
questions.correctAnswer: The grave and death cannot praise or celebrate God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:18 states that the grave cannot praise God nor can death celebrate Him, emphasizing the living's role in worship.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Hezekiah’s lament in verses 10-14?
options: Parallelism
Chiasm
Allegory
Hyperbole
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The lament in Isaiah 38:10-14 uses parallelism—a common Hebrew poetic structure—repeating and contrasting ideas about death and suffering.

questions.question: Who was Isaiah the prophet identified as in this chapter?
options: The son of Amoz
The son of David
A Levite priest
A disciple of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: The son of Amoz
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:1 identifies Isaiah as the son of Amoz, providing historical and genealogical context.

questions.question: What healing remedy did Isaiah prescribe for Hezekiah’s boil?
options: A lump of figs applied as a plaster
Anointing with olive oil
Prayer and fasting only
Water from the pool of Siloam
questions.correctAnswer: A lump of figs applied as a plaster
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:21 records that Isaiah instructed to apply a lump of figs as a plaster on Hezekiah’s boil, a remedy of the ancient Near East.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 38, how is God’s forgiveness portrayed in relation to Hezekiah’s soul?
options: God cast all Hezekiah’s sins behind His back
God punished Hezekiah without mercy
God ignored Hezekiah’s prayers
God required Hezekiah to perform sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: God cast all Hezekiah’s sins behind His back
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:17 speaks of God's loving deliverance and forgiveness, casting Hezekiah's sins behind His back.

questions.question: What is the significance of Hezekiah’s reference to the 'house of the LORD' in this chapter?
options: It symbolizes the place of worship and God's presence
It refers to the royal palace of Hezekiah
It indicates the temple in Babylon
It means the homes of the people of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the place of worship and God's presence
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:20 and 38:22 allude to the house of the LORD as the temple in Jerusalem, central to worship and divine encounter.

questions.question: True or False: Hezekiah’s prayer includes a request for God to 'undertake for me' because he felt oppressed.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:14 records Hezekiah saying, 'O LORD, I am oppressed; undertake for me,' showing his plea for divine help.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 38 foreshadow New Testament themes of resurrection and extended life?
options: Through God's miraculous extension of Hezekiah’s life and healing sign
Through detailed laws about life extension rituals
Through prophecies about the Messiah's earthly reign
Through genealogies linking to Christ
questions.correctAnswer: Through God's miraculous extension of Hezekiah’s life and healing sign
questions.explanation: The extension of Hezekiah’s life and the sundial sign in Isaiah 38 prefigure New Testament themes of resurrection and divine healing.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 38 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 38 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the initial message from the LORD delivered by Isaiah to King Hezekiah regarding his sickness?
options: Set thine house in order: for thou shalt die, and not live
You will recover and live many more years
Prepare for battle against Assyria
You will see a great sign in the heavens
questions.correctAnswer: Set thine house in order: for thou shalt die, and not live
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:1 clearly states that the LORD's message through Isaiah was that Hezekiah should set his house in order because he would die. This reflects God's sovereign judgment, consistent with other biblical passages on divine judgment (e.g., 2 Kings 20:1; Psalm 90:10; Hebrews 9:27; Ecclesiastes 3:2).

questions.question: How did Hezekiah respond when he was told he would die?
options: He turned his face toward the wall and prayed unto the LORD
He sought out a physician for healing
He gathered his officials to make war preparations
He ignored the prophecy and lived carelessly
questions.correctAnswer: He turned his face toward the wall and prayed unto the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:2 records that Hezekiah turned his face toward the wall and prayed, indicating a posture of humility and dependence on God in the face of death. Prayer as a response to crisis is a consistent biblical theme (e.g., Psalm 34:17; Daniel 9:3; Philippians 4:6; James 5:13).

questions.question: What reason did Hezekiah give in his prayer for God to remember him?
options: Because he had walked before God in truth and with a perfect heart
Because he had built many altars to the LORD
Because he had defeated the king of Assyria
Because he had wealth and power
questions.correctAnswer: Because he had walked before God in truth and with a perfect heart
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:3 reveals Hezekiah's claim that he had walked before God in truth and with a perfect heart, demonstrating a life of faithfulness. This reflects the biblical principle that righteousness and faith influence God's mercy (Genesis 6:9; Psalm 15:2-3; 1 Kings 9:4; 2 Chronicles 6:16).

questions.question: What extension of life did God promise Hezekiah after hearing his prayer?
options: Fifteen years
Ten years
Twenty years
Five years
questions.correctAnswer: Fifteen years
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:5 states that God promised to add fifteen years to Hezekiah's life, illustrating God's sovereign power over life and death (cf. 2 Kings 20:6; Psalm 91:16; Job 14:5; John 11:25-26).

questions.question: What sign did the LORD give Hezekiah to confirm His promise?
options: The shadow on the sundial of Ahaz moved ten degrees backward
A rainbow appeared in the sky
A dove landed on the temple
Fire came down from heaven
questions.correctAnswer: The shadow on the sundial of Ahaz moved ten degrees backward
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:7-8 describe the sign where the shadow on the sundial moved backward ten degrees, demonstrating God's miraculous control over creation, supporting His promise. This aligns with other biblical miracles affirming divine authority (Exodus 14:21-22; Joshua 10:12-13; Psalm 19:1; John 11:43-44).

questions.question: According to Hezekiah's writing, how did he describe his near death experience?
options: I said in the cutting off of my days, I shall go to the gates of the grave
I was healed immediately without any pain
I was taken to the temple for a sacrifice
I was visited by angels
questions.correctAnswer: I said in the cutting off of my days, I shall go to the gates of the grave
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:10 expresses Hezekiah's despair about death, referring to going to the gates of the grave, illustrating human mortality and the universal experience of death (Psalm 23:6; Ecclesiastes 12:7; Hebrews 9:27; Revelation 1:18).

questions.question: How did Hezekiah metaphorically describe his life being cut off?
options: Like a weaver cutting off a thread
Like a tree being uprooted
Like a soldier defeated in battle
Like a river drying up
questions.correctAnswer: Like a weaver cutting off a thread
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:12 uses the metaphor of a weaver cutting off a thread to describe the end of life, emphasizing the fragility and brevity of human existence, consistent with biblical imagery (Job 7:6; Psalm 39:5; James 4:14; Isaiah 40:6-8).

questions.question: What was Hezekiah's emotional state as he looked upward during his sickness?
options: Oppressed and mourning as a dove
Joyful and hopeful
Indifferent and distracted
Angry and defiant
questions.correctAnswer: Oppressed and mourning as a dove
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:14 depicts Hezekiah as oppressed and mourning like a dove, reflecting the deep sorrow and spiritual distress in the face of death, similar to other biblical laments (Psalm 42:11; Lamentations 3:19-24; John 11:35; 2 Corinthians 1:8).

questions.question: What theological truth does Hezekiah acknowledge regarding God's actions in his life?
options: God both spoke and performed what He declared
God is silent and does not intervene
God punishes without warning
God’s plans are hidden from men
questions.correctAnswer: God both spoke and performed what He declared
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:15 affirms that God has spoken and fulfilled His word, highlighting divine faithfulness and sovereignty, consistent with biblical doctrine (Numbers 23:19; Psalm 33:11; Isaiah 55:11; Hebrews 6:18).

questions.question: According to Hezekiah, what is the source of life and recovery for the spirit?
options: The Lord, who recovers and makes alive
Human effort and wisdom
Material wealth and possessions
Astrological signs and omens
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord, who recovers and makes alive
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:16 teaches that life and spiritual revival come from the Lord, emphasizing divine grace as the source of true life, consistent with Scripture (Psalm 36:9; John 6:63; Ezekiel 37:5; Romans 8:11).

questions.question: How does Hezekiah describe God's love in relation to his deliverance?
options: God delivered his soul from the pit of corruption out of love
God ignored his prayers despite his love
God punished him severely because of sin
God's love was conditional on sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: God delivered his soul from the pit of corruption out of love
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:17 emphasizes God's loving deliverance from death, illustrating the doctrine of grace and forgiveness (Psalm 103:4-5; Lamentations 3:22-23; Romans 5:8; Ephesians 2:4-5).

questions.question: What does Hezekiah say about the grave and death in relation to praising God?
options: The grave and death cannot praise or celebrate God
The grave is a place of eternal praise
Death is a gateway to worship
The dead will sing praises before resurrection
questions.correctAnswer: The grave and death cannot praise or celebrate God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:18 teaches that the dead cannot praise God, highlighting the importance of life and conscious worship, which aligns with biblical teachings on the living glorifying God (Psalm 6:5; Ecclesiastes 9:5-6; Luke 16:22-26; Revelation 14:13).

questions.question: Who does Hezekiah affirm will praise God?
options: The living, including himself and future generations
Only the angels
Only the priests in the temple
Only the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: The living, including himself and future generations
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:19 states the living shall praise God and that fathers will teach their children, emphasizing the continuity of worship and the ecclesiological principle found throughout Scripture (Psalm 145:4; Deuteronomy 6:7; Acts 2:42-47; Hebrews 12:1-2).

questions.question: How does Hezekiah describe the LORD’s readiness to save him?
options: The LORD was ready to save me, so we will sing songs all our lives
The LORD delayed salvation until the last moment
The LORD refused to save despite prayers
The LORD’s salvation was uncertain
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD was ready to save me, so we will sing songs all our lives
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:20 expresses confidence in God's readiness to save, leading to lifelong worship, reflecting the biblical motif of salvation inspiring praise (Exodus 15:2; Psalm 40:3; Isaiah 12:2-3; Revelation 5:9-14).

questions.question: What remedy did Isaiah prescribe for Hezekiah’s boil?
options: A lump of figs laid upon the boil
Anointing with oil and prayer
Bathing in the Jordan River
Applying honey and herbs
questions.correctAnswer: A lump of figs laid upon the boil
questions.explanation: Isaiah 38:21 records Isaiah's instruction to use a lump of figs as a plaster, demonstrating the use of natural remedies alongside divine healing, consistent with biblical examples of medicinal practices (Exodus 15:26; Jeremiah 8:22; Luke 10:34; James 5:14).
